heading: greenspan sends stocks reeling
subheading: while the fed chief had some cheerful things to say about the economy, investors zero in on two words regarding inflation: "upside risk." wall street goes into a tailspin. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: leave it to al. wall street was lower thursday after big al greenspan served up his usual buffet of mixed messages and ambiguities. although the fedatollah had some positive words to say about the us economy, investors latched on to his observation that declining unemployment poses a greater "upside risk" of inflation.this, of course, is quite true, as any econ 101 student can attest. as to whether the fed actually sees inflation creeping into the picture, greenspan didn't say. but with the g-man, you take when you get.the dow jones industrial average dropped 89.34 points to 10866.07 in midafternoon trading, and the wired index was 7.60 lower at 636.13. the nasdaq composite index fell 43.81 to 2490.64, and the s&p 500 was down 20.14 at 1327.17.not everyone, however, took greenspan's words as a forecast of increased tornado activity. some were quick to point out that recent economic stats suggest that inflation remains nowhere to be found."any other interpretation doesn't jibe with the market," insisted arthur russell, an analyst with edward jones.indeed, the us labor department announced just prior to greenspan's speech that the number of americans filing for unemployment benefits rose last week after two straight weekly declines. a more telling indicator will be released friday when the government reveals its april jobless numbers. the unemployment rate is expected to stick to a 29-year low of 4.2 percent.besides, getting past that one little "upside risk" remark, the fedmeister seemed decidedly optimistic about us economic prospects. he said there's "compelling" evidence that increased labor productivity will be long-lasting, and was particularly enthusiastic -- if such a word can be used in describing greenspan -- about advances in technology.the "perceptible quickening in the pace at which technological innovations are applied," he said, indicates that "the recent acceleration is not just a cyclical phenomenon or a statistical aberration, but reflects -- at least in part -- a more deep-seated, still developing, shift in our economic landscape."translation: tech may keep boosting the economy.microsoft (msft) certainly thinks so. the software giant advanced 25 cents to us$79.38 after saying it will purchase a $5 billion stake in at&t following the telco's $54 billion acquisition of cable operator mediaone group. the alliance sets the stage for stuffing the windows operating system into set-top cable boxes throughout the country.for its part, at&t (t) surged $4.69 to $61.63 now that it's poised to become america's largest cable company. mediaone (umg) rose $2.44 to $79.31, while comcast (cmcsa), which came up short in bidding for mediaone's affections, slid 69 cents to $35.94.and in ipo action, an outfit called portal software (prsf), which makes applications for online customer billing, tripled to $42.50 after debuting with 4 million shares starting at $14 apiece. portal software has some high-tone clients, including uunet technologies and leading telcos. it lost more than $17 million in the latest fiscal year.
